MoSDAY, April 24,

From the standing committee on Standing Orders Mr. Gillis reported favorably on the petition for a charter for the Edmonton Club, and favorably on a petition for amendment to the Calgary General Hospital Ordinance, recommending granting of permission for introduction of Bills on the respec­tive subjects. The report respecting Calgary Hospital recommended the re­funding to the petitioners of the $100 fee deposited with the Clerk of the House.

COURT RECORDS.

Dr. Patrick asked: Have any repre­sentations been made by this Govern­ment to the Government of Canada as to the need of provision being made for the safe keeping of such records of the Supreme Court as are in charge of the deputy clerks of the Court?

Mr. Haultain's reply was in effect: Yes; the matter had been brought to the attention of the Minister of Justice time and again,_-the fact being that not only in the *ś districts but in one of the judicial districts there were no proper means for the safe-keeping of the valuabl documents of the court.

CALGARY FAIR GRANT.

Dr. Brett asked : Is it the Govern­ment's intention to assist by a grant of money the proposed midsummer fair at Calgary? Mr. Haültain replied that the Esti­mates for the year had been placed in the hands of members, containing all the financial propositions of the Gov: ernment for the year; they contained no grant to the Calgary fair, and the hon. gentleman could take it for ranted therefore that the Government id not propose to ask the House to vote such a grant.

DIVISION ON THE QUESTION OF LAND REGISTRATION DISTRICTS

Dr. Patrick, seconded by Mr. Rosen­roll, moved the following resolution :­Resolved that the power to make Ordinances in relation to the classes of subjects now dealt with by the “Lands Titles Act 1894,” should be vested in this Legislative Assembly, and that two lands registration districts, each served by one registry office would be

uite sufficient to serve the needs of the people of these Territories.

Dr. Patrick referred to the fact that one of the powers of the Assembly was to legislate on the º: of property and civil rights, such legislation being, however, subject to federal Act—the Laud Titles Act—so far as land titles were concerned. It would be readily agreed that in the days of immature organisation it was ºil. that the administration of so important a sub­ject as land titles should remain under control of Parliament. But now that the Territories have a comparatively large legislature, with an array of legal talent, and a presumably fair know­ledge of the subject, the time had come when the Assemby should be entrusted with the management of the registra­tion system. One good reason for the request for the transfer was that the system was being maintained expen­sively. For the past seven years the average cost had been $17,500 yearly, with average receipts, of $10,500. The fees were very high, ranging from $4.35 upwards. The cost of effecting the transfer of a $25 lot was $4.35 which everyone must admit was in­ordinately excessive. A noticeable fact was that very great difference prevailed between the proportionate receipts and expenses of the various offices—there were five offices. Regina Yºry much more than paid expenses. The Calgary and Edmonton offices' receipts and expenses ran about even, with the expensés of the former slight­ly higher. #. expenses of the Prince Albert office had always exceeded the income, and at Battleford, while the Sillary of the late registrar was $2,000, the receipts had ranged from $70 to $120 annually. Small wonder that the expenses of the system were $7,000 in excess of the income. It was his be­lief that with a reduction to two offices the expenses could be reduced so as to not only make the system self­supporting but to lessen the fees . fifty per cent. Before the branc roads—the C. & E. and P. A. branches -had been constructed, there was pro­bably some reason, if not absolutely sound, for the maintenance of the outside offices, but now there was reasonably quick communication be­tween .# parts of the country to

ermit of registration ... business eing done by mail. He under­stood that legal firms right in towns

where registry offices exist, do their business with the offices by mail for the sake of keeping the records in their ºwn letter books. He would point out that if there was any good reason for an office at Battleford, there was , equ­ally gºod reason for offices at Yorktón,

in Souris district, and at several other | P. places. If there was need for five offi­

§§§, there was equal need for ten. In this department every extra office

cost of the system had been reduced somewhat, but was still in excess of the receipts. The receipts of the vari: ous offices in the last Dominion fiscal ear were: Regina, $7,427.33; Edmon­on, $2,485.45; Calgary, $3,531.60: Prince Albert, $737.50; Battleford, $82.29. The Battleford office was now vacant, which was one reason for his resolution. Here was an opportunity to lessen the expense. He did not know of an appointment, being made to the vacancy, and the resolution would be fair warning to any applicant for the position that he need expect no consideration when the system was transferred to that Assembly. Mr. Haultain was sure that everyone would agree to the first part of the pro­position. They all knew that in their work of .# they very frequent­ly ran up against the federal Land Tit: les Act, which curtailed and restricted their powers of legislation. The mem­orial on that part of the subject was by no means new. It was a matter of É. convenience, and there could e no question that the local legislature was the proper body to deal with, and should have power to deal, unrestrict­

edly with, questions of property and civil rights. In very many of the subjects With which

they had to deal, as for instance, schools, local improvement, noxious weeds, the question of land and land titles was involved. There were now of course sections in the federal Act making sales under the Assembly's authority practicable, yet there would be many advantages if the system were wholly transferred to the legisla­ture. Mr. Haultain referred to the requests made for the transfer in for­mer years, and read to the House a representation made by this Govern­ment to Ottawa last January. On the second question of the resolution he could follow Dr. Patrick's argument to a large extent. There was no doubt that the system should be centralised. The very basis of the system was cen­tralisation. The service would be bet­ter and more ºpy met by a reduced number of offices. Yet he thought it would be better not to involve the House in a discussion on that point at this time—when the Assembly had the power it would be early enough for them to debate the matter of reduc­tion. It was needless now to ask the members for Edmonton or Battleford or Prince Albert to agree that when we got the power the offices in their respective districts should be abolished. Sufficient for the day was the evil thereof. He quite agreed with , the argument that the system should be centralised, but the first proposition was the important one for the present. The transfer of the system would result in more complete and efficient Territorial legislation, and he believed they could give good service and at the same time greatly reduce the cost of land transactions. He would be sor to see the first question mixed up wit controversial matter which could not in any case be decided now. - Mr. McKay (Prince Albert), said if the mover would amend the resolution as º by the Premier, he would be glad to sup­port it, otherwise he would have to 5ppose. It would be soon enough to discuss the second question when the Assembly had power to deal with it. Dr. Patrick said he had no intention of so amending it. The purpose of the second proposition was to serve as a warning to any applicant for the Bat­tleford vacancy- . - Mr. Bennett—There is one appointed. Dr. Patrick—Well, this resolution will lead him to expect short shrift when this Assembly gains control. Dr. Brett regretted that the contro­versial portion of the resolution was ... The first proposition would be unanimously approved. The se, cond portion might jeo ardise the good proposition. e would like to see the resolution amended. - -- idr. Patrick—I have no objection to your moving an amendment. A division being called for, the names were taken down as follows: Yea—Messrs. The operation of the proposals of the bill would tend to .*g. the breeding of pure bred econd reading agreed to. DENTISTRY.

Mr. Brown moved second reading of a bill to amend the Dentistry Ordi­nance. One principal change proposed was to .."; a reciprocity provi; sion as affecting British Columbia and Manitoba. Like the Territories, those rovinces are not in a position to grant #. diplomas, but issue licenses. Their licenses are now recognised by us, while they do not recognise ours. The bill, provided for reciprocity, in recognition or otherwise. The bill would also prevent the admission here of men bearing diplomas from certain foreign dental institutions which do not require certain courses of instruc­tion,-institutions which grant diplo­mas to men without their serving an apprenticeship, without their attending lectures, etc. The admission fee was roposed to be raised from $25 to $50. he fees in Manitoba and B.C. are $100. Another provision required den­tal candidates to have literary stand­ing equivalent to N.W.T. second class non-professional certificate; and, for Territorial dental students, prescribed attendance for at least one year at some recognised dental institution. Second reading agreed to.

IRRIGATION DISTRICTS.

Mr. Cross proposed for second read­ing a bill tº amend the Irrigation Dis­tricts Ordinance. . The amendment provided that a two-thirds majority §hall be necessary to the formation of a district. The present law operates on a bare majority. Mr. Cross said he was thoroughly in favor of the rinciple of the irrigation law; and #. and believed it would eventually !jºin great good for the country.

very much trouble and litigation. He }. petition from owners in that dis­trict–owners holding 70 the land, but who found themselves in the minority, and did not wish to see the responsibility assumed of giving power to borrow and tax to the extent ermitted. In the district of Spring­ank the loan may ,amount to $4.00 § acre of all irrigable land, in ad­ition to which a . tax up to $1.00 an acre may be levied... In reality or­ganisation under the Ordinance makes owners liable to enormous debt, and this fact, backed by the experience in the one district organised, convinced him that almost perfect unity and har­mony should prevail in any district on the question of organisation, before success in the operation could be ex­pected. For these reasons he proposed to raise the necessary majority to a two-thirds vote. Mr. Bennett said that the one irriga­tion district in the Territories was in West Calgary, and the law firm of which he was a member had had charge of one side.of the litigation that had arisen in connection; he had, therefore, some knowledge of the mat­ter. Mr. Bennett believed there was not a better drawn or sounder Ordi­nance in the book, no Ordinance that would so well stand testing,-no Ordi­nance of more value to the public É. than the Irrigation Districts rdinance: the fruit of the long study and exceeding care of the Thighest authority on the subject who could he found in Canada, the present deputy commissioner of public works for the Territories. The Ordinance, sofarasits provisions related to the expenditure of money, was based on the Wright Act, in force in many States, and about which there had raged the fiercest legal warfare. Mr. Bennett urged that if his colleague from Calgary was fearful of giving power even to majorities, he should commend him to take another look at Sec. 2 of the Villages bill; how­ever, that had nothing to do with the question. Mr. Bennett deplored any attempt to change the law now, if for nothing else but the possible effect on Springbank. Irrigation district. The litigation, the interminable sºits, had at last been ended. . Any change might disturb the unanimity, now prevailing and destroy the organisation. Nothing was so disastrous, detrimental, ruinous as troºvie between neighbors. Affairs ware now going smoothly. One man who had been a plaintiff in a suit against the district was now one of the trustees of the district, Mr. Ben­nett said a two-thirds majority would be unworkable; it would mean that no district could be organised. There would always be four out often men, 7 out of 20,-averse to organisation. In the Springbank district were some large land owners who cared, nothing for the agricultural interest of the district. Behind the petition for this amendment were only these kickers, He would not .#. second reading but suggested sending the bill to one of the standing committees and get Mr. Dennis’ views. Mr. Ross was pleased to know that the members for Calgary were one in expressing faith in irrigation. He re­ferred briefly to the origin of the Ordi­nance, and to the troubles engendered in the Springbank district. The people there, he was glad to kuow, were get­ting past those troubles and were now in a fair way to success. He believed that a great deal of the friction,-the loug continuation of the trouble, was due to the fact that the people of the district were so evenly divided—it was almost a deadlock; and he believed Mr. Cross' amendment would tend to prevent such trouble. A two-thirds vote would ensure a fair working majority, and districts formed by a two-thirds vote would not be in danger of the friction which retarded work in Springbank. Mr. Ross pointed, out that between this Ordinance and the Village law, referred to by Mr. Ben:

nett, there was a whole world, of difference. The taxing possibilities could not be compared. He informed

the House that the bill had been dis­cussed with Mr. Dennis, who was, as Mr. Bennett said, a recognised author: ity on the subject—having attended many of the irrigation conventions in the United States and given long and thorough study to the question,-and who, both to the Dominion govern­ment when they exercised the direc­tion, and to this Government, had iven most valuable advice. The bill É. been discussed with Mr. Dennis, and he could say the Department ap­proved the bill. He pointed out that it was not retroactive—it could have no effect in the Springbank district. Agreed. AGRICULTURAL SOCIETIES.

The Commissiouer of Agriculture moved second reading of a bill respect­ing Agricultural Societies, Qne prin­cipal provision was to facilitate the amalgamation of the smaller societies for show, purposes. . Mr. Bulyea in­stanced the union of the Indian Head, Qu'Appelle and Fort Qu'Appelle socie­ties which now held joint... shows very successfully. The bill pro­osed to vary the method of distri­É. of grants. At present there was no direct encouragement to large membership. It was now proposed to divide the grants on per capita basis. The new method of distribution, apply­ing to local grant, would not come into force until next year, but would be followed this year in apportion­ing the federal grant of $7,000 which this Government was asked to distri­bute. After this year, all grants would be paid on the basis of member­ship of the previous year. The annual meetings of societies would be held in each December, and the grants for the year would be available as soon as the Assembly passed Supply—early in the new year. Next December the societies will get the grant for 1899, and a couple of months later that for 1900. So next year all societies will have a double ortion, and will be put on good foot­ing. , In, addition, to the per capita ants, there would be grants given ; show purposes, the maximum for any societ .#Fº at $1,000. To be allowed to hold a show and partici­ate in this grant, a society would É. to devote at least $350 of its own money. This provision would not pre­vent any society from holding a show at least each alternate year. Mr. Meyers asked if any distribution was to be made this year. He heartily approved the general principle of the bill, , but thought that societies in special situa­tions should have special provision made for them. Dr. Brett º: the bill as far as it went, but held that it did not go far enough. A change was necessary. He was led to believe that in the past the shows had come down to this, that a very few individuals made exhibits andrakedinthegrants, whileentirelyne­: glecting any discussion on agricultural topics. He would be in favor of bonus­ing large shows—permanent or regular shows, like the Western Fair at Lon­don, for instance;—have one good one in East Assiniboia, and other iistricts. Mr. Simpson asked if the second principle would not do away with the ! smaller societies. Mr. Bulyca-No, the idea is simply to enable small societies to unite for show purposes. Mr. Simpson feared that under the bill the usefulness of the small society —its local usefulness—would be gone. He did not favor that feature. Dr. Elliott also protested against that pºple. and against the views of Dr. rett. This country was entirely different as yet from the eastern pro­vinces. In Ontario good shows could # be found everywhere within ten miles. : The condition here was that if the farmer was deprived of the local show, he might have to go thirty miles to the other. It was impossible to take show animals any such distance... He had known valuable animals to die on the trail while going to the show. The proposition seemed to him to discrimi­nate against the rural communities in favor of the towns. In Wolseley dis­trict—at Pheasant Forks, 33 miles from the railway—he had last fall attended a show, a most successful show where the competition was keen. He would be safe in saying that 300 people were present from the local neighborhood, and he was sure that not forty of those people could get in to attend a show in the railway town. The cited instance of amalgamation in Qu'Appelle district was a special case, with conditions especially favorable for amalgamation. Fort Qu'Appelle was a beautiful spot which would draw people. Dr. Elliott was against, tagk­ing agricultural shows to the tail of a horse race. He believed that shows in the east were deteriorating. Mr. Cross disagreed entirely from Dr. Elliott, and was only sorry that

the grant for shows was limited to $1,000. He believed central shows to be very much more beneficial than the local ones. The Winnipeg, fair as an advertisement for Westein Canada was worth more than all the other fairs combined. In Ontario he knew that stock breeders attached very high importance to prizes won at Toronto.

Mr. Wallace was inclined to support Dr. Elliott's view. The shows were ill­tended to be educational, and when lmeld in the towns those who needed the education were unable to attend. Locally, he would favor amalgamation —he had advised amalgamation in the case of three small societies in his dis­trict, and, indeed, had favored the scheme of all those societies joining in 8, §. show this year at Calgary, but only for this one year.

Dr. Patrick was ready to try almost anything that promised betterment. In the F. the shows held locally had cer­tainly not given value for their cost— not for any fault of management, so much as on account of conditions. The conditions here did not lend themselves readily to the system pursued with suc­cess in Ontario. In the fall farmers were too busy to attend fairs. It seem­ed to be a case of now trying the sum­mer fair.

Mr. Bennett favored the bill. On this subject the Government had attempted with a large measure of success to § with a difficult, problem. It was difficult to satisfy both city and country, and the Government was en­titled to sympathy. The bill would en­courage largé shows, but would not do away with the small societies, it would please both city and country. He would like to see the limit for show grants raised to $2,000.

Mr. Ross believed he had been one of the first to denounce the class of shows being held, which of course did not mean denouncing the societies;–they had dome a great and good won The present bill would not restrain the energy of any society; it was not in the direction of the doing away with a single society, but simply would en­courage better shows byamalgamation. It should not be forgotten, too, that to hold shows was only a small part of the possible usefulness of a society. If to hold shows was their only §ed. he had no hesitation, in saying they were not worth the grants. He thought Mr. Wallace's reference show­ed that the bill was just what was wanted. . Those High River societies could under it combine and hold agood show. There was no compulsion in the bill—the societies were left free. The High River societies were not forced to join with Calgary, but Mr. Ross believed they could do so once in a few years with good results. It was only in the towns that a fair of any proportions could be held—small places could not offer the necessary accommo­dation. Proceeding, Mr. Ross contend­ed that if a society could not have 150 members, there was evidence of a lack of interest on the3. of the people of the locality,+evidence to warrant a

doubt as to the , advisability of per­mitting a show to be held. ut take a society of 100 members. Its own

fees—$100; local grant—$100; federal grant—$155; total—$355; such a society in , alternate years could have $700 for a show. He would advocate fewer and better shows. In the past by having them too frequent­ly societies were neverstrong financial­ly. The bill would, he hoped, stimulate that feature of every society's work, and still encourage the other features: the holding of meetings—the keeping the people together for interchange of ideas and mutual help—the bringing of experts to impart the results of study and experiment. Mr. Smith... representing a purel

agricultural district (Moosomin) ". produced .# that contributed to an agricultural show, admitted that the system in the past had been ac­complishing less and less. The Mooso­min fair had of late not been of the most desirable character, con­sidering the important position of the town, on the borders of Manitoba. A show in such a place should be of a class to impress visitors. He heartily favored the bill, and was glad that the small societies were not to lose their plage.

Mr. McKay failed to find in the bill

or large. He thought, however, the

The policy had apparently been changed since then. F. McKay believed they were pur­suing the right policy now. Mr. McCauley was glad that for once he was able to agree with Dr. Brett and Mr. Bennett. he bill was in the right direction and might well have gone farther. Mr. Brown, ºft been connected with probably the oldest society in the Territories, took deep interest in the subject. The bill took away no right now possessed by the smaller societies, but its intent was to encourage larger and better shows. It was only the prizes gained at the large shows that were really worth much. A breeder did not take his stock to shows for the sake of the prize itself, but for the reputation he night gain for his stock: reputation meant money to the stock raiser. The worth of the large show was shown by the value placed on a Toronto or a Winnipeg prize. He knew that high value was attached to prizes won at the Territorial fair. Mr. Gillis foresaw two difficulties— the small societies would be hard to get together, and the matter of ac­commodation for joint fairs would be a serious question. However anythin which promised to increase the useful­ness of the society work was well worth trying. TOWN OF MINTO.

... Mr. McCauley procured second read: ing for the Town of Minto bill, and had it committed to the Municipal Law committee, which committee would * a delegation from South Edmon­Im. The House sat until 6:30 o'clock, Mr. Speaker being persuaded to turn his watch back one hour. The Partner­ship bill, Noxious Weeds bill, Law So­ciety, bill, Inspection of Stock bill, Winding-up bill, and Civil Justice bill got their final touches in committee of the whole and were reported for third reading. Mr. McLeod submitted an amend­ment to the Local Improvement law, to provide that owners of land in lots less than ten acres be assessed at 25 cents per acre, instead of the arbitrary $2.50 per plot. Mr. Ross accepted the amendment. The amendment, will meet an excep­tional case at Prince Albert, where outside of the town limits a consider­able area had been divided into town lots, before incorporation, which lots are held by several hundreds of owners each at present liable to $2.50 local im­provement tax. FENCEs.

Mr. Rosenroll's Fences bill occasioned a lot of discussion. Mr. Simpson, for the purpose of preventing delapidated fences remaining as a nuisance and menace to stock, desired to incorporate a $100 penalty clause against the main­tenance of any other but a legal fence. Mr. Lake strongly objected, holding that the clause would render liable nine-tenths of thesettlers of Assiniboia. Dr. Patrick pointed out that the only purpose of a Fence Ordinance was to prescribe the conditions under which a man could sue for damages fortrespass in his crops. Mr. . Simpson's clause failed to carry.

The bill proposed to do away with the exceptions of the present law, and make one law |. to the whole country. Lawful fences may be any fence four feet high consisting (a) of 4 rails or boards,the lower not more than 18 inches from the ground and panels not more than 12 feet; (b) upright posts or palings not more than 6inches apart; (c) barbed wire and top rail, not less than two wires, the lower not more than 20 inches from the ground, posts not more than 164 feet apart, with one dropper; (d) three wires, posts not more than 35 feet apart, wires fastened to wooden or wire droppers not more than 7 feet apart; (e) “A” supports, three rails on one side and at least one rail firmly secured on opposite side; (f) woven wire on posts not more than 35 feet apart; , (g) or any river bank or other sufficient natural boundary.

Summary of Preliminary ‘Business Disposed of Before the Commence­ment of the Financial Statement for 1899–Total Expenditure for the Year Estimated to be $413,000.

TUESDAY, April 25.

The House met at 2:30.

Dr. Brett asked: What were the outstanding liabilities of the Govern­ment on 31st IDecember last?

Mr. Ross explained that a month was allowed for the closing of the accounts of each financial year—up to the end of the succeeding January. ... At the end of January there were no liabilities on account of the year 1898—all ac­counts received had been paid. There had been, of course, some debts still due —for services in regard to which the accounts had not come in by the end of January, or had not come in in proper form. Such matters as those were provided for in the Estimates in the hön. gentleman's hands.

Two bills by Mr. Bulyea were given first reading, one to add a certain area to Indian Head municipality, and one to amend the present Agricultural Societies Ordinance which will not be superseded by the new Ordinance until the end of this year. MR. VILLENEUVE WANTED TO PLACE HIMSELF.

Mr. Villeneuve moved the adjourn­ment of the House for the purpose of fº the fact noted that § he had been present on the previous day he should have voted against Dr. Patrick's resolution favoring the reduction of the number of registry offices to two.

Dr. Patrick regretted that Mr. Ville­neuve showed less faith in Edmonton than the hon. member for Edmonton (Mr. McCauley), who voted for the resolution confident in the belief that if the proposed reduction took place, Edmonton would be the location for the western office.

TELE BUDGET SPEECH.

MR. ROSS rose to introduce the Es­timates, and was received wiih hearty applause from all sides of the House. e said that in rising to make the motion that stood in his name he might say that he regretted exceeding­ly—and he felt satisfied that every member of the House would join him in the regret—that the motion had not been made by the leader of the House, who had on every previous occasion since it had been the privilege of the Executive to present the estimates, discharged the duty of presentin those estimates. That regret .# be especially felt by the old members because they all knew from experience that in previous years when this mo­tion was made by the leader of the House it was invariably one of the bright spots of the session. (Hear, hear.) Mr. Haultain always succeed­ed in presenting a statement that was not only clear and lucid to a degree, but he also placed the matter of it be­fore the House in an exceedingly inter­esting form; and he (Mr. Ross) was sure that every one of the members who heard those statements had bene­fitted very largely by the information with regard to the powers of the As­sembly, our relations to the Dominion Government, and the position of the country generally, which was contained in those statements of the hon, gentle­man from Macleod. A RETH:OSPECT. But in the re-arrangement of the departments he (Mr. Ross) had assum­ed the position of Territorial Treasurer and therefore on the present occasion it was his duty to make the annual financial statement; and as a new treasurer meeting a new, House con­taining an unprecedentedly large pro­portion of new members and who were meeting under almost new conditions —he thought under those conditions he would be pardoned if he he went back a "little—if he be­came a little historical, and took a dip as it were into the past. He would take them back to the formation of the first Council of the Territories—to the first financial statement that was brought down. That was in the year 1878; and they would find that at that period the total revenues were $526 made up of $328 in fines, and $138 from licenses. He might say that in that year no ex­penditure was made, and all that enor­mous sum of $526 was placed in the bank at Winnipeg with the exception of $40.50 which was retained by the Lieut.- Governor presumably to meet unprovided for or unexpected contin­encies. The next statement brought own covered a period from July 1878 to 1879. The revenues appeared to have fallen off somewhat while the expen­diture appeared to have increased. As the revenue which was derived from licenses—which he supposed meant per­ruits—and fines had decreased in that year, he fº he was justified in assuming that the country had become more moral after the first year of a $.” regimie in the Territories. 'rom that eriod he would move on to the first Estimates prepared and forwarded to Ottawa by the Council. In 1879 and '80 the gov­ernment of the Territories applied to Ottawa for certain sums for expendi­ture in the North-West. On looking back he found that many of the ser. vices now being performed by the North-West Government were being performed by the government of that time, while some of the services then. performed had been eliminated from the present list of services.
